unnormalised: The first time I heard about a personal loan was from my cousin, Priya. She worked as a software engineer in Bangalore and wanted to prepone her wedding. “Rs. 5 lakhs should do it, I think,” she said, scrolling through different bank websites on her laptop. I remember being shocked - ₹5,00,000 seemed like an astronomical amount to borrow!

I remember being shocked - rupee five hundred thousand seemed like an astronomical amount to borrow!

unnormalised: Fast forward a couple of years, and it was my turn to consider a loan. My auto-rickshaw, my bread and butter, was sputtering its last. Repairs would cost Rs. 20,000, a sum I just didn't have readily available. I knew that without it, feeding my family would become extremely difficult.

Repairs would cost rupees twenty thousand, a sum I just didn't have readily available. I knew that without it, feeding my family would become extremely difficult.

unnormalised: I’d always been wary of banks. The forms, the jargon…it all seemed so complicated. But a friend, Rajesh, suggested I check out the Mudra loan scheme. "Lower interest rates, bhai!" he told me, "and less paperwork than a regular loan." He mentioned the local branch of SBI, where he’d heard they were quite helpful.
normalised: I’d always been wary of banks. The forms, the jargon…it all seemed so complicated. But a friend, Rajesh, suggested I check out the Mudra loan scheme. "Lower interest rates, bhai!" he told me, "and less paperwork than a regular loan." He mentioned the local branch of S-B-I, where he’d heard they were quite helpful.

unnormalised: So, with a mix of hope and trepidation, I walked into the SBI branch near my home. The officer, a young woman named Ms. Sharma, was surprisingly patient. She explained everything in simple Hindi, even the bit about the 12% interest. We filled the forms, I submitted my Aadhaar and PAN card copies, and waited. After what felt like an eternity – actually, it was about 2 weeks – my loan of Rs. 25000 was approved!

After what felt like an eternity – actually, it was about two weeks – my loan of rupees twenty five thousand was approved!

unnormalised: The relief was immense. I got my auto fixed within a week. The repayments were manageable, spread over 36 months at Rs. 833.33 per month. It pinched, especially during the monsoon months when business was slow, but it was better than nothing. I even started putting aside Rs. 50 a day, just in case another emergency came up.

unnormalised: Looking back, I realize that loan wasn't just about fixing my auto; it was about giving me a sense of security. And it taught me a valuable lesson: sometimes, a little financial help can go a long way, especially when life throws a ₹20,000 repair bill your way.
